issue_description:
# Test frontend services _This is intended as a starter project for newer contributors but if you're already a contributor for some time, you can help as well._ NOTE: Please ping @nithusha21 if you have any questions about this issue or would like to be assigned to some part of it. In order to prevent future regressions, we want to ensure that all services in our frontend codebase are thoroughly tested. If it's your first time here, please read carefully the guide of how to get started with frontend unit testing: [Guide for writing frontend tests](https://github.com/oppia/oppia/wiki/Frontend-unit-tests-guide). **Please use this guide as your helper, all the instructions of how to test properly is in it**. Also, here is Oppia's wiki page for [running the client-side Karma tests](https://github.com/oppia/oppia/wiki/Running-Tests#client-side-tests). The services are separated by three levels of complexity: | Complexity | Easy | Medium | Hard | |:---------------:|:----------------:|:---------------:|:------------------:| | Number of lines | up to 100 lines | up to 250 lines | at least 250 lines | Then, it doesn't matter if you're new to unit test or if you're looking for something more challenging, there will be service for you work with. Each file is marked with two information that will help you to decide which service to pick. For example: - [ ] **A - B** service-name.service.ts A means the service complexity: E for Easy, M for medium and H for Hard. B means if the service has a spec file: Y for Yes and N for No. Spec files for services tests consist of the name of the service, followed by `.spec.ts` or `Spec.ts`, it depends of the service file name structure: - Use `.spec.ts` for services like: service-name.service.ts - Use `Spec.ts` for services like: ServiceNameService.ts When writing tests, if a spec file already exists for the service you have picked, then edit the existing file. If a spec file isn't present yet, create a new file and name it accordingly. You can also take a look at the existing spec files for different services to get an idea on how to get started. _Note: We are currently in the process of upgrading AngularJS to Angular. If the service is written in AngularJS, write the test in AngularJS. If the service is written in Angular, write the test in Angular. We would also prefer to cover all Angular files before moving to AngularJS files to prevent extra work during the migration._ **If you'd like to help with this issue, please select a file from the list below, comment on the thread with the file name or any query you'd like to be assigned, and submit a PR when you've completed writing the test. Once the PR is submitted, you can tick the checkboxes.** PR's for reference: [#4135](https://github.com/oppia/oppia/pull/4135) #8916 #8934 ---- **Files to write tests for or increase until 100%:** **Angular files** - issue_comments.body: Would it be better to split this into multiple issues (say one per directory)? That way multiple people could work on it simultaneously.
I think one issue should be fine -- we already follow this pattern for our other [starter projects](https://github.com/oppia/oppia/wiki/Contributing-code-to-Oppia#-as-a-new-contributor).
Hey, @shubha1593 Can I take "ExplorationEmbedButtonService.js". Hopefully, it will help me to better my understanding of testing processes and writing specs.
Hi @Nix07, yup sure! assigned you :)

This is the screenshot of my karma index page at core/templates/dev/head/components/ Why is it not showing any directory inside the components. It's only giving the results for the JS files present in components directory! However, when I bring the "ExplorationEmbedButtonService.js" file in the components directory its result is visible. Please help @shubha1593 
![components](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/22103406/32457393-00c73d54-c34f-11e7-88ab-21f4e5de09ce.png)
@shubha1593 please assign me editor_tab
Hi @GaganSuneja, assigned you :)

Hey @Nix07, in your URL for that it would be like `...karma_coverage_reports/core/templates/dev/head/components/index.html`, 
make it  `...karma_coverage_reports/index.html`. Let me know if this works!

Hey, @shubha1593 It didn't help. karma_coverage_reports/index.html just contains all the directory (see the screenshot). To get the result of a specific file, I have to go to that directory. 
![karma](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/22103406/32528440-11573b00-c459-11e7-8a10-03f9871b3157.png)

I just tried this, and I run into the same issue as @Nix07.

So I investigated the script at scripts/run_frontend_tests.sh, and, from there, the karma config at core/tests/karma.conf.js. The config actually looks a little off to me, so I simplified it, and I think it works now -- see #4066
Also, @Nix07, thanks for bringing it up! This is a great bug to catch and I'm happy we're fixing it.
Hi can I write tests for domain/learner_dashboard?
@nithusha21, Sure! I've assigned you.
Hi @shubha1593 , can I take services/stateful?
Hi @aks681, Sure! assigend you. :)
HI @shubha1593 ,can i take domain/classifier?
Hi @jervis446, sure, assigned you.
Hi i am intreseted in taking and working on this issue. Assign me this

Hi @yashLadha, welcome :) Have you followed these steps given [here](https://github.com/oppia/oppia/wiki/Contributing-code-to-Oppia#setting-things-up) to get started? Also, let me know which part you would love to work?

Yes @DubeySandeep . I am intrested in python based web frameworks and also done a certification course in Angular. So would be comfortable with Angular as well. But i am not limiting myself to this only and i am open for learning. :smile:
@yashLadha, That's great! Can you just let me know in which part of this issue you would love to work?
@yashLadha, I've assigned you to domain/utilities.
Sure @DubeySandeep
Hi @WickedBrat, You can start working on ' domain/collection' part. I've assigned you.
Hi @yashLadha, how is it going (the work on domain/utilities)? :)

Working on it. Fixed another issue. Can I send pr for that.

text_context:
# Test frontend services _This is intended as a starter project for newer contributors but if you're already a contributor for some time, you can help as well._ NOTE: Please ping @nithusha21 if you have any questions about this issue or would like to be assigned to some part of it. In order to prevent future regressions, we want to ensure that all services in our frontend codebase are thoroughly tested. If it's your first time here, please read carefully the guide of how to get started with frontend unit testing: [Guide for writing frontend tests](https://github.com/oppia/oppia/wiki/Frontend-unit-tests-guide). **Please use this guide as your helper, all the instructions of how to test properly is in it**. Also, here is Oppia's wiki page for [running the client-side Karma tests](https://github.com/oppia/oppia/wiki/Running-Tests#client-side-tests). The services are separated by three levels of complexity: | Complexity | Easy | Medium | Hard | |:---------------:|:----------------:|:---------------:|:------------------:| | Number of lines | up to 100 lines | up to 250 lines | at least 250 lines | Then, it doesn't matter if you're new to unit test or if you're looking for something more challenging, there will be service for you work with. Each file is marked with two information that will help you to decide which service to pick. For example: - [ ] **A - B** service-name.service.ts A means the service complexity: E for Easy, M for medium and H for Hard. B means if the service has a spec file: Y for Yes and N for No. Spec files for services tests consist of the name of the service, followed by `.spec.ts` or `Spec.ts`, it depends of the service file name structure: - Use `.spec.ts` for services like: service-name.service.ts - Use `Spec.ts` for services like: ServiceNameService.ts When writing tests, if a spec file already exists for the service you have picked, then edit the existing file. If a spec file isn't present yet, create a new file and name it accordingly. You can also take a look at the existing spec files for different services to get an idea on how to get started. _Note: We are currently in the process of upgrading AngularJS to Angular. If the service is written in AngularJS, write the test in AngularJS. If the service is written in Angular, write the test in Angular. We would also prefer to cover all Angular files before moving to AngularJS files to prevent extra work during the migration._ **If you'd like to help with this issue, please select a file from the list below, comment on the thread with the file name or any query you'd like to be assigned, and submit a PR when you've completed writing the test. questions_generated: What is the purpose of separating services by complexity in the Oppia repository?
How should a contributor decide whether to create a new spec file or edit an existing one when writing tests for a service in the Oppia repository?
What is the significance of the ongoing AngularJS to Angular migration for contributors working on frontend tests?
Explain the naming convention used for spec files in the Oppia repository and why it is important.
What steps should a contributor follow if they have questions or need assignments for frontend service testing in the Oppia repository?
Describe the role of the LearnerDashboardBackendApiServiceSpec.js file in the context of testing the LearnerDashboardBackendApiService.
Why is it important for the Oppia repository to have a detailed guide on writing frontend tests, and how does it benefit new contributors?
What is the significance of the 'Globals.TRANSLATOR_PROVIDER_FOR_TESTS' in the LearnerDashboardBackendApiServiceSpec.js file?
How does the error handling mechanism in the LearnerDashboardBackendApiServiceSpec.js file contribute to the robustness of the service?
golden_answers_generated: The separation of services by complexity (Easy, Medium, Hard) helps contributors, especially newer ones, to select tasks that match their skill level and comfort. This categorization ensures that there are appropriate tasks available for contributors of varying experience levels, allowing them to contribute effectively while gradually taking on more challenging tasks as they become more experienced.

A contributor should first check if a spec file already exists for the service they have selected. If a spec file exists, they should edit the existing file to add or improve tests. If no spec file exists, they should create a new one following the naming conventions: '.spec.ts' for services like 'service-name.service.ts' and 'Spec.ts' for services like 'ServiceNameService.ts'.

The ongoing migration from AngularJS to Angular means that contributors should prioritize writing tests for services written in Angular before those written in AngularJS. This approach helps prevent redundant work and aligns with the project's goal of completing the migration efficiently. It ensures that the Angular services are fully tested and stable, which is essential for a smooth transition.

The naming convention for spec files in the Oppia repository is '.spec.ts' for services named like 'service-name.service.ts' and 'Spec.ts' for services named like 'ServiceNameService.ts'. This convention is important for consistency, organization, and ease of locating test files related to a specific service. It helps maintain a clear structure, especially in a large codebase, making it easier for contributors to navigate and manage the tests.

If contributors have questions or need assignments, they should ping '@nithusha21', who is responsible for managing this issue. This process ensures that contributors receive the necessary guidance and are assigned tasks that align with their skills and the project's needs.

The LearnerDashboardBackendApiServiceSpec.js file contains unit tests for the LearnerDashboardBackendApiService. Its role is to ensure that the service functions correctly by simulating various scenarios and verifying that the service's behavior aligns with the expected outcomes. This testing helps prevent regressions and ensures that any changes to the service do not introduce bugs.

Having a detailed guide on writing frontend tests is crucial because it provides clear instructions and best practices for testing, which is essential for maintaining high code quality. For new contributors, this guide acts as a valuable resource that helps them understand the testing framework, the structure of test files, and the specific expectations for test coverage. It accelerates their onboarding process and empowers them to contribute effectively with confidence.

The 'GLOBALS.TRANSLATOR_PROVIDER_FOR_TESTS' is used to provide translation capabilities during the tests. It ensures that any internationalization or localization features are accurately tested. This is important for verifying that the service behaves correctly across different languages and locales, which is a critical aspect of ensuring a seamless user experience in a multilingual environment.

The error handling mechanism in the LearnerDashboardBackendApiServiceSpec.js file contributes to the robustness of the service by simulating error scenarios, such as server errors, and verifying that the service responds appropriately. This testing ensures that the service can handle unexpected situations gracefully, providing meaningful feedback or fallback options, which is vital for maintaining reliability and user trust.
